sections: Managing Editor Joel Warner is based on reporting for his new book:
The Curse of the Marquis De Sade: A Notorious Scoundrel, a Mythical Manuscript, and the Biggest Scandal in Literary History

of public pension dollars into private equity. After all, these assets have a history of sterling returns ‚Äî why would they run into trouble now?

The problem is that private equity portfolios are not only opaque, but also built on illiquid assets ‚Äî investments like restructured companies that have no transparent public valuation and cannot be easily converted into cash. To understand why this is so dangerous, let‚Äôs look to an unlikely source: a scandal across the Atlantic involving the original manuscripts of some of the world‚Äôs most famous literary works, from Andr√© Breton‚Äôs surrealist manifestos to Charlotte Bront√´‚Äôs early writings to a long-lost scroll of the Marquis de Sade.

The tale is centered on a genteel Left Bank neighborhood in central Paris, an area said to boast more antiquarian booksellers and document dealers than anywhere else on the planet. Here, in cramped, dusty shops, illuminated manuscripts, intimate letters penned by historical greats, and autographed first editions have long commanded international attention and astronomical prices.

But the market was small and insular, fueled by a handful of expert dealers and the fervor of a few thousand high-end clients. That changed in the early 2000s, when a local upstart investment company called

began selling joint ownership shares of collections of letters and manuscripts for a few hundred euros on up. Suddenly, teachers, police officers, shopkeepers, and others making a modest living all over Europe could own a piece of the country‚Äôs celebrated literary heritage ‚Äî and earn 40 percent returns in five years, promised the independent advisors touting the operation.

Everybody made money ‚Äî the booksellers, the investors, and most of all, Aristophil. The company amassed one of the largest private collections of letters and manuscripts in the world ‚Äî including Napol√©on‚Äôs love notes to Josephine, Isaac Newton‚Äôs personal notebooks, and fragments of the Dead Sea Scrolls.

And since Aristophil‚Äôs contracts were structured as private deals, there was little the country‚Äôs stock market regulator could do but issue a tepid warning about ‚Äúatypical investments‚Äù such as letters and manuscripts.

. Police raided Aristophil, seizing everything. They claimed the company was an elaborate Ponzi scheme, in which new investments were used to pay off old ones in order to make the operation appear sound as it grew ever bigger. Aristophil‚Äôs steadily rising rates of return were being driven by ever-more generous estimates provided by the company‚Äôs well-compensated document specialists. Such hefty markups were never challenged, since Aristophil functioned as a closed system. Once acquired, its books and manuscripts were never put up for sale at public auction.

While the head of Aristophil is still awaiting trial, the company has long been liquidated. To help recoup the ‚Ç¨850 million that 18,000 shareholders had invested in the operation, France sold off Aristophil‚Äôs 135,000 holdings in a series of

. While certain items fetched decent prices, the vast majority of sales revealed the company‚Äôs valuations were vastly overblown. On average, shareholders lost ninety percent of their investments. For many, this was their entire savings; one investor committed suicide. The only winners were the booksellers who‚Äôd been paid hefty fees to inflate the value of Aristophil‚Äôs holdings, since they now snatched up materials at rock-bottom prices.
After attending one of these auctions, where many items were left unsold or went for far less than their estimate, one witness declared he had witnessed a ‚Äúblack sale.‚Äù

The rise and fall of Aristophil isn‚Äôt just a cautionary tale for those considering buying into U.S. joint-share art investment companies like Masterworks and Yieldstreet. Substitute private equity stakes for literary manuscripts, and the French disaster is a warning for millions of schoolworkers, firefighters, first responders, and other government employees ‚Äî because
t of all pension dollars are now invested in private equity assets.

Both the rare documents amassed by Aristophil and the companies bought up by private equity firms are illiquid assets ‚Äî assets that are rarely sold, and don‚Äôt have a firm public value, like cash or shares of stock on a public exchange. Private equity firms have used this fact to engage in what

, using secret metrics that, as the Center for Economic and Policy Research

For its part, the Biden administration has
a rule to increase transparency of private equity funds and limit preferential treatment offered to some investors. But it has
a Trump-era rule that allows public retirement plan administrators to shift ever-more pension money into these private equity timebombs.

The same sort of overzealous valuations were at play during the 2000s housing bubble, and they could once again lead to catastrophe. We‚Äôve already seen the first signs of trouble: Last year, the mammoth California Public Employees' Retirement System unloaded a $6 billion private equity portfolio at a
‚Äî $600 million less than what private equity managers had valued it.

Like the high-end dealers and collectors in the Aristophil scandal, sophisticated operators will weather the pending private equity implosion. Private equity managers will take the massive fees they‚Äôve earned and buy up the distressed companies left behind, while savvy investors are already
to avoid the bloodletting. But thanks to the
employed by private equity, the vast majority of public pension fund managers ‚Äî and government employees whose retirement savings are on the line ‚Äî have no idea what could befall them.

It‚Äôs fine for experienced, high-net-worth individuals to bet their own money on alternative investments, just like wealthy collectors have long dabbled in the rare-book trade. But this is different: This is public officials gambling public pensioners‚Äô retirement savings on opaque and risky schemes.
Something has to be done, and soon, or there could be more black sales on the horizon.
